intro: Trinia ramosissima subsp. longipes, commonly known as the long-stemmed trinia, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly in regions of Argentina and Chile. It belongs to the Acanthaceae family and is characterized by its slender, branching stems and clusters of small, tubular flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and is known for its ability to thrive in arid conditions. Its flowers, which are usually pink or violet in color, bloom in the spring and attract various pollinators such as bees and butterflies. This subspecies is of interest to botanists due to its unique morphology and ecological adaptations.
